security_audit.summary: Documentation and example code repository with no malicious behavior. Contains educational MCP server examples with appropriate security practices including environment variable handling, input validation, and path traversal protection. All risk factors are intentional capabilities for legitimate MCP server development.

low_findings.title: File system access in example servers
low_findings.description: Resource server examples include file reading capabilities (resource-server.py:571-582) with path traversal protection: `filepath = os.path.abspath(filepath)` and directory restrictions. This is legitimate for documentation/resource servers but represents filesystem access capability.

low_findings.title: Network requests to external APIs
low_findings.description: Advanced server examples make HTTP requests to GitHub API and Weather API (advanced-server.py:451-523). Endpoints are legitimate: api.github.com and api.openweathermap.org. Network capability is intentional for API integration servers.

low_findings.title: Environment variable access for configuration
low_findings.description: Code reads environment variables for API keys and configuration (advanced-server.py:70-74). This is standard secure practice for secrets management. Documentation explicitly warns against hardcoding credentials (security-guide.md:245-246).

content.user_title: Build MCP Servers for Claude Integration
content.value_statement: Claude needs standardized access to external tools and data sources. This skill provides complete guidance for building Model Context Protocol servers that expose custom tools, resources, and prompts to Claude safely and securely.
actual_capabilities: Create MCP servers with tools, resources, and prompts
Build REST API wrappers for external services
Design effective JSON Schema tool definitions
limitations: Requires Python 3.10+ and MCP SDK installation
Network access depends on server implementation
File system access is server-specific and configurable

use_cases.title: API Integration Servers
use_cases.description: Wrap REST APIs as MCP tools so Claude can query external services like GitHub, weather, or databases.

use_cases.title: Documentation Resources
use_cases.description: Create resource providers that give Claude access to internal documentation, knowledge bases, and guides.

use_cases.title: Custom Tool Servers
use_cases.description: Build specialized tool servers for domain-specific operations like database queries, cloud resource management, or CI/CD.

prompt_templates.title: Simple Server
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a minimal MCP server with one tool called search_database that accepts a query parameter and returns results. Show the complete Python code using the MCP SDK.

prompt_templates.title: Tool Definition
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to define a tool with proper JSON Schema including required fields, default values, and enum constraints. Give a complete example.

prompt_templates.title: API Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an MCP server that wraps a REST API with authentication. Include environment variable handling, error handling, and response formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Production Server
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to configure an MCP server for production use including rate limiting, logging, health checks, Docker deployment, and graceful shutdown.

output_examples.input: Create an MCP server with a calculator tool
output: Basic calculator server with add, subtract, multiply, divide, and power tools
Tools are registered with clear descriptions and JSON Schema validation
Error handling for invalid inputs including division by zero
STDIO transport for integration with Claude Desktop

best_practices: Use environment variables for all secrets and API keys, never hardcode credentials
Validate all inputs with JSON Schema and implement additional runtime validation
Add path traversal protection and directory restrictions for file system access
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys or credentials in source code
Skipping input validation on tool arguments
Using relative file paths without security checks

faq.question: What languages support MCP server development?
faq.answer: Python and TypeScript have official MCP SDKs. Other languages can implement the JSON-RPC 2.0 protocol.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of tools an MCP server can provide?
faq.answer: There is no hard limit, but practical servers typically expose 5-20 tools for usability. Group related functionality into focused servers.

faq.question: How do MCP servers communicate with Claude?
faq.answer: MCP servers use stdio transport (local) or HTTP with SSE (remote) to exchange JSON-RPC 2.0 messages with clients.

faq.question: Is data sent to MCP servers secure?
faq.answer: MCP runs locally on your machine. Servers only receive data you explicitly pass. Use environment variables for secrets and validate all inputs.

faq.question: Why is my MCP server not appearing in Claude?
faq.answer: Check that the server starts correctly, uses absolute paths in configuration, and returns proper tool definitions from list_tools handler.

faq.question: How does MCP compare to function calling?
faq.answer: MCP provides a standardized protocol for tool discovery, authentication, and resource access. It works alongside function calling with richer capabilities.
